@HeckoX 
In the case of the rocks explained in this video, they're spherical due to gradual wear and tear over hundreds of thousands of years. This wear and tear is caused by the molecules in water, wind, and/or the surface it rolls on, grinding against the molecules on the surface of the rocks, weathering them into spherical (or disc) shapes.

@dya230 
SchumiUCD got there before me; even if we were to assume that the molecules that make up the object had a strong enough bond that they wouldn't split apart from the centrifugal force, it would never be a sphere. At some point, it would come close, but would then become more and more like a disk, as the force pulling away from the centre would gradually become greater, since it moves at bigger speeds the further from the centre it gets.

I...i like the stick figures better.:(

@PeterRockClausen There's no proven answer to that, but it's been hypothesized that it was an evolutionary mechanism to give us more traction on wet and slippery things! Try holding one hand in water until it gets wrinkly, then wet down a shampoo bottle and see which fingers are easier to grab with, the wrinkly ones or the smooth ones. :) I know I'm not Minute Physics Guy, but I hope this was a little informative!

@dya230 There are two things here. First is how solid the object is: if you spin a paving slab, it won't become round. It'll either stay the same shape or (if you spin it really fast) break. Something like a lump of wet clay will become more round if you spin it though. 

Secondly, this roundness isn't a sphere, it will be more like a disk. Material will be pushed away from the axis of rotation. This happens the Earth to a small extent, it's wider at the equator than from pole to pole.

@dya230 
The moon doesn't spin on its own axis, it just wobbles. Try image googling 'moon wobble gif' for an example.

Also, if you spin a piece of clay around one axis, the force that shapes it is called centrifugal force, which is more or less the exact opposite of gravitational force (pulls away from the centre rather than towards).

But no, it wouldn't turn into a sphere, but rather splatter on the walls. Think kids flying off a fast-spinning merry-go-round in a park.
